Posts.Title: Biopsy today sheila1951 Shappy

Posts.Content: sheila1951 wrote: Well, just had my MRI guided biopsy.  I was sure hoping they wouldn't find the mass on the 2nd MRI and I could "pull up my big girl panties" and go home.  Not so lucky.  It was uncomfortable at best.  I had a crying session in the MRI room before hand so they gave me something to calm me down.  Felt like a big baby but the gals there were TERRIFIC.  I suggest anyone in Kansas go to Cypress Women's Imaging if they have to have anything done.  I should have my report back late Monday afternoon or Tuesday at the latest.  Hope I can keep occupied this weekend and stay busy at work on Monday.  The old saggy girl is sore but not unbearable.  If this is as sore as it gets then I'll be fine with it. Prayers and hugs to all waiting on their results. Sheila/Kansas Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy today sheila1951 Shappy

Posts.Content: sheila1951 wrote: I am freaking out.  Short background: Lump biopsied 1.5 years ago (diagnosed as adipose tissue) has grown and changed "feel". Dr sending me for MRI and possible biopsy scheduled for Monday.  I don't have PAIN but can feel discomfort in the area.  I can feel the lumps sides on 3 sides but not the fourth....its like it fades away.  I measure it to be about 2.5 to 3 cm now.  It was only 1.5 when I found it.  I have always heard that if you find a lump and there is not pain that it is b9.  I think it was the look in the surgeon's eyes when he felt it that freaked me out more than anything.  has anyone else felt the disconfort/burning area in their lumps?  What does that mean?  The area is the left breast, left upper quadraant if that matters. I've had too many coctails so should go to bed but your imports means alotl My grandmother and Mother dealt with BC for maaaaaanu years. I'm thinking of having the BRCA2 test run...if is positive I will have suckers get a rid of me. Sheila from Kansas. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Waiting on results of 2nd biopsy - can't think straight anymore brady0819 Karen3

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 03:12PM sheila1951 wrote: brady0819....I feel your worry.  I've been testing, waiting, biopsying, waiting, testing and getting ready for lumpectoming for months now.  I have found that keeping busy PHYSICALLY is very helpful.  Heck, I even tore the carpet out of my dining room and I am removing the stain on the old hardwood floor board by board.  My husband just looks at me like I'm insane for doing this but also understands the need to keep busy. I was finally diagnosed with a intraductal papilloma a month ago after mammo, sono and MRI guided biopsy.  My surgeon wasn't satisfied with the "benign" path report either.  I have a long family background of BC so it has been decided that the area with margins needs to be excised to make sure there is no cancer hiding in there.  I'm having this done on October 1st.  I had pretty much calmed down after the biospy but now my gut is rolling again and I can't keep my mind off of what "might be".  I'm not too bad right now but by next Thursday I will be a wreck. Try to keep your spirits up...hard to do but not impossible.  And keep in touch. Sheila/Kansas
Posts.Title: Waiting on results of 2nd biopsy - can't think straight anymore brady0819 Karen3

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2009 05:56PM sheila1951 wrote: Jeanne, Sounds like you are going thru the same things I have been going thru for the last 6 months or so.  I have 2 lumps in my left breast. Neither one have been detected by mammo or sono.  One is benign....core needle biopsy a year ago.    The other one is about the size of my finger from tip to first joint.  When I first discovered it I saw the same surgeon who did the core needle.  He suggested I wait 30 days and he would re-check it.  Went back and he suggested I wait another 30.  Then wait 3 months.  He feels it is normal breast tissue.  (A little background....my Mother and Grandmother both died from breast cancer....I have had 4 or 5...hard to remember how many...B9 biopsies).  On Tuesday this week I went in for my "annual" mammo....I've had 3 on the left breast this year!  Anyway, after the films were done I did my "sit and wait till we see if the pictures took" routine.  I have NEVER had to had a "retake", so didn't think anything about it.  Tech came in and took compression pictures on BOTH breasts.  The left was aimed at the existing "wait and see" lump.  I don't know what they were looking for on the right.  I had microcalfications removed from that one several years ago.  I can't feel a lump on the right. So now I wait for the mammo results which I should get next week sometime.  I have been thru this so many times that I really don't get too shook up till I hear the nurse on the phone saying they have the results.  Then I want to puke.  It is scary as heck but like I said, all of my biopsies have been B9 .... I pray yours is too! I'll try to let you know my latest mammo results.  By the way, I will be 58 on Sunday and am generally healthy and active!

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2009 08:54PM sheila1951 wrote: I had an intraductal papilloma excised on Thursday.  Is that the same as a ductal excision?  My nipple is flat as a pancake.  I am still having alot of pain under my arm as well.  Do they check sentenal nodes when they do this?  Maybe that is why there is so much underarm pain.  My incision is about 3/4 way around my nipple and the papilloma was very deep so they had to go almost to my chest wall.  I'm to find out path reports next week.

Posts.Title: MRI & Stereotactic biopsy sheila1951 sheila1951

Posts.Content: sheila1951 wrote: Well, I had my 3 month check on the lump beneath my left nipple.  It hasn't changed and the surgeon is still convinced it is normal breast tissue.  As he was doing his exam he re-examined the lump I had a core needle biopsy on a year ago.  He kept feeling and kept feeling then had the medical student with him feel it as well.  I knew it was bigger than it was but since the biopsy results came back benign a year ago I hadn't given it a whole lot of thought.  Dr. told me to get dressed and he would be back in a few minutes.  When he came back he had the deer in the headlights look about him and told me that he was alarmed that it had grown so much and certainly had a distinctly different feel to it.  He told me that this is not one of those situations where you recheck it every month or so.  He told me I had to have an MRI and possibly a stereotactic biopsy as soon as possible.  His assistant will call me tomorrow with date and time.  I wasn't all that nervous when I went in but that changed within minutes.  I'm not afraid of the MRI or any pain with the biopsy if they do one.  It's the outcome.  Long Long family history of BC.  BTW....this lump has never been seen on a mammo or sono. Sheila Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 03:05AM - edited Aug 15, 2009 03:06AM by sheila1951 I too have an appointment with a breast surgeon next Wednesday.  According to my MRI readings I am to have a biopsy guided by either sono or MRI.  I doubt this will happen on Wednesday but wish it would.  I have been thru this so many times that this seems like a routine bad dream I have.  5 biopsies (all B9) in the past 15 or so years.  I worry, yet I don't worry.  I think I "stew" about it more than I worry.  Check every possible word from my MRI reports on the internet, read into every meaning that I have cancer.  Everyone hugs me and says that it will be alright.  Those are the ones who have never had to go thru this or wait for an appointment or wait for a biopsy and results. I have told my kids (once again) but I'm afraid they are beginning to think of me as the boy who cried wolf.  I kind of feel like that at times too.  My kids are 30, 38 & 39. (Had to stop and think about how old they are! :) Lets do a 3 way virtual hand holding and pray ourselves and each other to be B9.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 12:32PM sheila1951 wrote: The MRI machine used for my breast test was much larger in circumference and much shorter than the normal MRI machines.  It is made especially FOR breast MRI's.  Granted, you still have to lie still and you are still in a tube, but it is MUCH less scary.  Believe me, if I had to have had mine done in a regular MRI machine, I'd of chickened out too!  Open MRI's aren't bad either.  I have been in those as well.
